coredata.dc:title: A polyethylene oxide/metal-organic framework composite solid electrolyte with uniform Li deposition and stability for lithium anode by immobilizing anions

coredata.dc:description: All solid-state batteries (ASSBs) are regarded as promising energy storage batteries with high energy density and high safety. The polyethylene oxide (PEO)-based electrolyte with succinonitrile (SN) has attracted critical attention for its high ionic conductivity at room temperature. However, SN can react with Li metal to result in an unstable interface between electrolyte and electrode, which deteriorates the electrochemical performance. In this work, zeolitic imidazolate framework-67 (ZIF-67) is used as a filler to construct composite electrolytes and solve the aforementioned instability issue. The composite electrolyte shows nonflammability, high processability, and a competitive ionic conductivity of 2.78 * 10−5 S/cm at room temperature. Due to the regular dodecahedron structure and abundant Lewis acid sites, the composite electrolyte film exhibits a high Li-ion transference number of 0.654 and a wide electrochemical window of more than 5 V. Moreover, the ZIF-67 helps to construct a uniform and fast ion transport channel and can promote the generation of LiF to prevent SN from contacting Li anode, which contributes to the excellent stability of the Li symmetric batteries cycling for over 1000 h at a current density of 1 mA cm−2. And the assembled LiFePO4||Li batteries based on the composite electrolyte display high discharge specific capacities of 158.6 and 70 mAh g−1 at 60 °C and room temperature, respectively.

(a) The EIS of PSZ20 and PS20 electrolyte with stainless steel counter electrode at room temperature. (b) Arrhenius curves of ion conductivity for PSZ20 and PS20 electrolytes. (c) Polarization curve and initial and steady-state impedance diagram (the inset) for PSZ20 electrolyte at 25 °C. (d) TGA curves of PSZ20 and PS20 from 30 to 700 °C. (e) LSV for PSZ20 and PS20 electrolytes at 25 °C. (f) Impedance diagram of LFP |PSZ20 electrolyte| Li before and after 50 cycles.

Interface compatibility between PSZ20 electrolyte and Li metal anode. (a) Galvanostatic cycling curves of the symmetric Li batteries with PSZ20 composite electrolyte and PS20 electrolyte at 1 mA cm−2. SEM images of surface of (b, e) fresh Li anode and (c, f) Li anode with PS20 electrolyte after 100 cycling at 1 mA cm−2 (d, g) Li anode with PSZ20 electrolyte after 100 cycling at 1 mA cm−2.

Electrochemical properties of LiFePO4||Li all-solid-state batteries. (a) Charge and discharge voltage profiles under different rates obtained from LiFePO4|PSZ 20|Li cells at 25 °C. (b) Rate capability of LiFePO4|PSZ20 |Li and LiFePO4|PS20 |Li cells at 25 °C. (c) the cyclic voltammetry curve of LiFePO4|PSZ20 |Li cells. (f) Cycling stability obtained from the cells with PSZ20 and the cells with PS20 at 0.2C and 60 °C.

head.ce:title: A polyethylene oxide/metal-organic framework composite solid electrolyte with uniform Li deposition and stability for lithium anode by immobilizing anions

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: All solid-state batteries (ASSBs) are regarded as promising energy storage batteries with high energy density and high safety. The polyethylene oxide (PEO)-based electrolyte with succinonitrile (SN) has attracted critical attention for its high ionic conductivity at room temperature. However, SN can react with Li metal to result in an unstable interface between electrolyte and electrode, which deteriorates the electrochemical performance. In this work, zeolitic imidazolate framework-67 (ZIF-67) is used as a filler to construct composite electrolytes and solve the aforementioned instability issue. The composite electrolyte shows nonflammability, high processability, and a competitive ionic conductivity of 2.78 * 10−5 S/cm at room temperature. Due to the regular dodecahedron structure and abundant Lewis acid sites, the composite electrolyte film exhibits a high Li-ion transference number of 0.654 and a wide electrochemical window of more than 5 V. Moreover, the ZIF-67 helps to construct a uniform and fast ion transport channel and can promote the generation of LiF to prevent SN from contacting Li anode, which contributes to the excellent stability of the Li symmetric batteries cycling for over 1000 h at a current density of 1 mA cm−2. And the assembled LiFePO4||Li batteries based on the composite electrolyte display high discharge specific capacities of 158.6 and 70 mAh g−1 at 60 °C and room temperature, respectively.

ce:section.ce:para: At present, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are widely used in energy storage areas, for example, electric vehicles, mobile phones, and other electronic products [1–3]. However, most LIBs currently use flammable organic liquid electrolytes, which suffers safety risks [4–6]. All solid-state electrolytes (ASSEs) not only can improve safety but also possess higher energy density [7–10]. And solid-state electrolytes are one of the key factors in all solid-state batteries. Polyethylene oxide (PEO)-based solid electrolyte possesses prominent advantages [11–14], including good film-forming ability, low interface resistance, and excellent mechanical property [15–18]. Plastic crystal succinonitrile (SN) has been widely used to couple with PEO-based electrolytes to improve ionic conductivity [19–21]. SN not only can decrease the crystalline of PEO but also increase the solubility of lithium salt [22,23]. PEO/SN based electrolyte with lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulphonyl)imide (LiTFSI) can obtain high ionic conductivity of 1 * 10−3 S cm−1 at room temperature [24], so the PEO with SN is recognized as an electrolyte with practical application prospect. However, the PEO/SN-based solid electrolyte has poor mechanical properties, which will reduce the film-forming feature of polymer electrolyte and decrease the mechanical property [25]. Besides, SN is unstable in the PEO-based electrolyte because lithium metal can initiate polymerization of SN in polymer electrolyte [26,27]. Therefore, it is vital to solve the instability problem of PEO/SN electrolytes [28,29].

Ugata and his co-worker [30] found that SN and lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl)amide (LiFSA) can form stable solvates in the molar ratio of 1: 2. The [LiFSA]/[SN] = 1/0.8 electrolyte presented with a wide electrochemical window of 4.8 V. Hu et al. [21] prepared a new succinonitrile (SN)-based dual-anion deep eutectic solution by incorporating two lithium salts (lithium difluoro(oxalato)borate (LiDFOB) and LiTFSI). The above salts can react with lithium metal to form a film preventing the contact of lithium and SN. Zha [23] prepared a new SN-based solid electrolyte, in which electrospinning poly(vinylidene fluoride-co-hexafluoropropylene) (PVDF-HFP) fiber membrane was used as a framework, and ethoxylated trimethylolpropane triacrylate (ETPTA) monomers were incorporated in PVDF-HFP to polymerize.

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a potential filler in solid electrolytes [31–34]. MOFs can enhance the ionic conductivity of polymer electrolytes effectively with ample Lewis acid sites [35–38]. The characteristic framework structure of MOFs can confine the transport paths of Li+ and restrict the movement of anion groups [39–43]and thus significantly increasing the Li+ transference number. MOFs also can help Li+ to uniformly deposit on the anode side, inhibiting the side reactions between SN and lithium metal [32,39,44–46]. Wang et al. [47]. designed an asymmetric solid-state electrolyte using Zeolitic Imidazolate Framework-8 (ZIF-8) as a modification layer on the lithium anode side to suppress the lithium dendrites growth. Bai and his coworkers [48] also proved that MOF improved the stability of lithium by forming a homogenous three-dimensional Li-ion transport pathway.

In this work, different from other work, ZIF-67 was not used as a modified layer to absorb the polysulfides to solve the shuttle effect [25,41,47], instead acted as an inorganic filler in PEO/SN-based solid electrolyte. SN and ZIF-67 work together to increase the ionic conductivity of the solid electrolyte. At the same time, ZIF-67 could solve the instability problem caused by SN. Furthermore, ZIF-67 efficiently suppressed lithium dendrite growth and reduced the side reactions between SN and lithium metal. The composite solid electrolyte exhibited a high ionic conductivity of 2.78 * 10−5 S/cm and a wide electrochemical window of more than 5 V. Moreover, it possessed a high ionic transport number of 0.645 as well as low activation energy of 0.151 eV. The Li symmetric cell shows excellent cycle stability over 1000 h at 1 mA cm−2.

0.168 g Co (NO3) ·H2O (99%, Macklin), was solved in 50 ml deionized water and after stirring for ten minutes, 0.527 g 2-methylimidazole (98%, Macklin) was added in. Mix them in a beaker quickly, and stand for 4 h to make the ZIF-67 crystal grow to rods. The ZIF-67 was suctionfilter and dried to obtain purple powders.

1.5 g PEO (600,000, Macklin), 0.54 g LiTFSI (battery grade, Guangdong canrd New Energy Technology Co., Ltd) (EO:Li = 18:1), 0.3 g SN(99.7 %GC, Macklin) (20 wt% PEO), 0.075 g ZIF-67 (5 wt% PEO) were dissolved in 50 ml acetonitrile (99.7%, Macklin) and stirred for 12 h at 50 °C. The solution was poured into the polytetrafluoroethylene mold and stood for 12 h, and dried at 60 °C for 24 h to completely remove acetonitrile. The as-prepared sample was named PSZ20. For PS20, 1.5 g PEO (600,000), 0.54 g LiTFSI, 0.3 g SN were dissolved in 50 ml acetonitrile and stirred for 12 h at 50 °C. The other steps are the same as that of PSZ20.

LFP (battery grade, Guangdong Canrd New Energy Technology Co., Ltd), Super P (battery grade, Guangdong Canrd New Energy Technology Co., Ltd), PVDF (battery grade, Guangdong Canrd New Energy Technology Co., Ltd) and were mixed with the ratio of 8:1:1 to form a uniform slurry with NMP (battery grade, Guangdong Canrd New Energy Technology Co., Ltd) as solvent. The slurry was coated in aluminum foil and dried at 120 °C for 12 h. The film was cut into a 13 mm rounded cathode. The cathode loading is 0.168 mAh/cm2.

All batteries were assembled into CR2025-type coin cells with lithium metal as anode and the LiFePO4 as the cathode. The prepared solid electrolyte membrane was placed between cathode and anode. All cells were assembled in an Ar-filled glove box (O2 < 0.5 ppm, H2O < 0.5 ppm).

X-ray diffraction spectroscopy (XRD) is used to measure the degree of crystallinity of electrolyte membrane. The mechanical property was measured by a universal strength testing machine (CMT4304GD). The morphology of electrolyte membrane and lithium is measured by Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi, S-4800) and the element distribution of electrolyte is measured by Energy disperse spectroscopy (EDS). The thermogravimetric (TG) analysis of the electrolyte is carried out on a Mettler Toledo TGA/DSC 3+ at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 from 30 to 700 °C. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha+) is used to measure the chemical state of the samples.

The ionic conductivity of solid-state electrolyte (SSE) is analyzed by AC impedance of cells with ion-blocking electrodes at different temperatures ranging from 30 to 80 °C with 10 °C an interval. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) with a sweeping frequency from 1 mHz to 10 MHz and an AC amplitude of 5 mV at open circuit potential, is executed with a Zahner Autolab electrochemical workstation. The ionic conductivity is calculated according to the equation:
(2-1)
σ =
L
RS

σ is the ionic conductivity of the electrolyte, and L is the thickness of the electrolyte or the distance between two blocking electrodes. Where R is the bulk resistance of solid electrolyte membrane analyzed by the AC impedance, the S is the surface area of solid electrolytes.

The charge/discharge measurement of the batteries was carried out with the battery measurement system (NEWARE). The linear sweeping voltammetry (LSV) is recorded with an electrochemical workstation (CS2350H Bipotentiostat, Corrtest) from 2 to 6 V at a scanning rate of 1 mV/s. The redox potential of coin cell with LFP|SE|Li was performed at a scanning rate of 0.5 mV/s is measured by cyclic voltammetry (CV) from 2.2 to 4.2 V. The Li-ion transference number (
t
Li
+
) of SSE was calculated according to the equation:
(2-2)

where ΔV is the applied polarization voltage, which was set as 10 mV, I0 and R0 are the initial currents and initial interfacial resistance respectively. The ISS and RSS are the steady-state currents and steady-state interfacial resistance of the cell respectively.

The Li+ transport pathway and structure of PSZ20 composite solid-state electrolyte (CSSE) are illustrated in Fig. 1 . Lithium salt (LiTFSI), ZIF-67, and SN were uniformly dispersed in PEO. SN was functioned to improve the solubility between PEO and LiTFSI, decrease the crystalline of PEO and improve the ionic conductivity of the electrolyte. Meanwhile, ZIF-67 acted to fix anion as a filler, thus resulting in Li+ apace transport between cathode and anode. Moreover, ZIF-67 not only improved the Li+ transport number but also enable Li+ homogenous deposition for its regular dodecahedron structure. The ZIF-67 can effectively fix TFSI− in the frame structure and orderly distribute it on the lithium metal anode side. Therefore, TFSI− can preferentially react with lithium metal to generate a layer of LiF first. Because ZIF-67 promote the generation of LiF to prevent SN from contacting Li anode, it can improve the stability of PEO-SN electrolyte.

The preparation process of PSZ20 was illustrated in Fig. 2 a. The prepared ZIF-67 with a dodecahedral frame structure, lithium salt (LiTFSI), and SN were added into PEO to form a homogenous electrolyte membrane. Fig. 2a exhibits the optical image of the PSZ20 electrolyte. A flat and dense surface of electrolyte with a thickness of 100 μm was demonstrated in Fig. 2c–e. On the contrary, the uneven surface of the PS20 electrolyte was shown in Figure S1. The uniform distribution of C, F, and Co in the electrolyte membrane in EDS images (Fig. 2f–h) evidenced the good mixing of PEO, LiTFSI, and ZIF67. Considering the high content of ZIF-67 will make it agglomerate in the electrolyte, the addition of ZIF-67 is controlled at only 5 wt% of PEO.

EIS test was executed to calculate the ionic conductivity of electrolytes at room temperature. PSZ20 shows ionic conductivity of about 2.97 * 10−5 S/cm and PS20 shows ionic conductivity of about 1.44 * 10−5 S/cm at room temperature (Fig. 3 a), which was higher than that of pure PEO electrolyte membrane (Figure S2). The related reason is that SN and ZIF-67 can decrease the crystallization of PEO (Figure S3) and elevate the movement of PEO chains. Moreover, the ionic conductivity of PSZ20 increased at higher temperatures from 30 to 80 °C. According to the ionic conductivity of electrolytes at different temperatures, the activation energy was calculated. Both PSZ20 and PS20 show low ion migration barrier of 0.151 eV and 0.153 eV, respectively. And the strength test indicates that the PSZ20 electrolyte possesses excellent flexibility with fracture elongation of 788.7% (Figure S4). Lithium transference number
t
Li
+
of solid electrolyte was measured by polarization curve as well as initial and steady state impedance, which is an essential factor to estimate the mobility of Li ions. The high lithium transference number usually enables a homogeneous dispersion and deposition of Li+ because the formation of space charge layer is avoided the interface between electrolyte and lithium anode. Fig. 3c displays the polarization curve and initial and steady state impedance graph of Li|PSZ20 electrolyte| Li cell. Particularly,
t
Li
+
of PSZ20 composite electrolyte is as high as 0.654, four times higher than that of PS20 electrolyte with 0.136 (Figure S5) as well as polymer electrolytes (0.2–0.5). The high ion transfer number of the PSZ20 electrolyte is due to the anion (TFSI−1) being bound to the dodecahedral framework structure of ZIF-67.

The TGA results (Fig. 3d) evidenced that the decomposition of PSZ20 started from 400 °C, which is much higher than that of PS20 (250 °C), which demonstrated that the addition of ZIF-67 can reduce the danger of thermal runaway. LSV was also used to evaluate the electrochemical window (Fig. 3e). Both PSZ20 and PS20 electrolytes displayed wide electrochemical windows up to 5.4 V. But PSZ20 did not show a slight current peak f at 2.4 V as PS20, which indicated that PSZ20 had better electrochemical stability. LiFePO4| PSZ20|Li battery was assembled for charge/discharge test. The resistance of PSZ20 composite electrolyte increased from 2105.9 to 3947.5 Ω after 50 cycles, which suggested that the electrode/electrolyte interface constructed remained compatible and stable during the cycling.

The Li symmetrical batteries were assembled to measure the interface stability of electrolyte to lithium (Fig. 4 a). The PSZ20 composite electrolyte shows a better stable and continuous intercalation and de-intercalation of lithium at 60 °C (1000 h with 1 mA cm−2) than that of PS20 (450 h with 1 mA cm−2). The polarization voltage of PS20 electrolyte reaches 0.2 V, which is much higher than that of PSZ20 CSSE (0.07 V), demonstrating that ZIF-67 can improve the stability of electrolyte and Li anode and is consistent with the results of LSV test and lithium-ion transference number. As shown in Fig. 4b, the fresh lithium foil is flat and homogenous. An evenly Li+ deposition without dendrites can be obtained after 100 cycles of LiFePO4| PSZ20 CSSE | Li (Fig. 4d). After 100 cycles, the lithium foil with PSZ20 electrolyte is as flat and smooth as the fresh lithium foil, forming a very uniform and stable lithium deposition. However, with PS20 electrolyte, an uneven solid electrolyte interface (SEI) film is formed on the surface of lithium foil, which is not beneficial to the cycle of the battery (Fig. 4e–g). This is because ZIF-67 can effectively inhibit the side reactions between electrolyte and Li metal, and the special and regular framework structure makes the migration of Li+ more orderly, leading to more homogenous lithium deposition. PSZ20 as electrolytes of all-solid-state cells are beneficial to uniform Li+ deposition.

All-solid-state batteries were assembled to carry out a series of electrochemical measurements. The rate performance of ASSBs was shown in Fig. 5 a-b. The LiFePO4|PSZ20 CSSE |Li battery exhibits 166, 154, 143, and 120 mAh g−1 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, and 0.5C under 25 °C, respectively. The energy density and power density are 547.4 Wh kg−1, 500.7 Wh kg−1, 456.1 Wh kg−1, 370.3 Wh kg−1 and 55.91 W kg−1, 110.5 W kg−1, 162.9 W kg−1, 266.4 W kg−1, respectively. The result demonstrates that the specific discharge capacity recovers to 167 mAh g−1 (567.8 Wh kg−1) when the rate comes back to 0.1C, indicating the prominent rate performance of LiFePO4 cells with PSZ20 electrolyte. Fig. 5c displays the cyclic voltammetry curve of LiFePO4|PSZ20 CSSE |Li batteries, suggesting that a pair of redox peaks appear at 3.92 and 2.71 V. The redox peaks are reversible without obvious side reactions. It partly proves the stability of PSZ20 electrolytes with LFP cathode and Li anode. As shown in Fig. 5d, the charge/discharge voltage profiles of batteries at 0.5C indicate that the battery with the PSZ20 composite electrolyte has a weak polarization augment over 100 cycles. The specific capacities of battery with PSZ20 composite electrolyte are 70, 70.1, 67.2, and 61.4 mAh g−1 at 1st, 20th, 50th, and 100th cycle with a cutoff voltage of 3.9 V, respectively. The initial specific capacity of the battery with the PSZ20 composite electrolyte is 70 mAh g−1 (energy density: 239.8 Wh kg−1, Power density: 272.5 W kg−1) and the capacity retention is up to 87.7% after 100 cycles at room temperature (Fig. 5e). However, the battery with the PS20 electrolyte can only charge and discharge 10 cycles under the same conditions even the specific capacity is 153 mAh g−1(Figure S6) and energy density is 520.2 Wh kg−1, which can be assigned to severe polarization. The outstanding cyclic stability of PSZ20 is mainly due to the compatible ionic conductivity, high Li-ion transport number, and a desirable electrolyte/electrode interfacial resistance. Fig. 5f shows the excellent cycling performance of LiFePO4|PSZ20|Li compared to LiFePO4|PS20 |Li batteries with 0.2C at 60 °C. The initial specific capacity of the battery with PSZ20 is 158.6 mAh g−1 (energy density: 579.5 Wh kg−1, power density:124.4 W kg−1) with a high capacity retention of 92.3% after 70 cycles at 0.2C, indicating the stable electrode/electrolyte interface during cycling.

In order to clarify the suppression effect of ZIF-67 on the side reactions of SN, the chemical information of Li anode after cycling was measured by XPS. All XPS spectra and peaks were calibrated to C 1s of 284.8 eV [49]. ZIF-67 is added in electrolyte and the addition amount is very small, so XPS didn’t show a sign of Co. Monochromated Al Kα (1486.6 eV) X rays were used to collect these data on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer. Passing energy (PE) of 150 eV was used. Original data have been fit using the commercial software XPSPEAK41. As shown in Fig. 6 a, The C 1s spectra are deconvolved into five peaks at 284.8, 286.2, 288.1, 289.2, and 292.4 eV, which are corresponding to CC, CN, CN, OCO, and CF3, respectively [32,50–52]. The CN and OCO peaks can be attributed to the decomposition of SN and PEO on the Li surface. The peak component in Li with PSZ20 electrolyte is similar to PS20 electrolyte, which proves that the ZIF-67 cannot react with the Li anode. Three peaks appeared at 397.1, 398.5, and 399.5 eV in N 1s spectra correspond to the Li3N, CN, and CN, respectively [26,50]. The existence of Li3N and CN indicates the polymerization of SN on the Li anode. The F 1s spectra at 684.6 eV and 688.1 eV indicate the presence of LiF and -CF3 on the Li surface, which is the result of TFSI− decomposition [31] (Fig. 6e,f). The peak intensity of LiF with PSZ20 is higher than that of PS20, which means the ZIF-67 promotes the generation of LiF. The intensity of -CF3 obviously decreased in PSZ20 than in PS20, which also means ZIF-67 boosts the formation of LiF. The existence of mechanically stable LiF contributes to inhibiting the side reactions between Li anode and SN.

In general, a polyethylene oxide/metal–organic framework composite solid electrolyte with a regular metal–organic framework was obtained. The ZIF-67, with the confinement effect on large volume anions and its regular framework structure, was incorporated to conquer the instability of electrolytes. A remarkable Li+ transport number of 0.654 and a wide electrochemical window of 5.4 V were obtained. The Li symmetry battery displays high stability with a cycle life of more than 1000 h at 1 mA cm−2. Moreover, the LiFePO4|PSZ20 |Li batteries also exhibited excellent cycle stability and desirable capacity at both 60 °C and room temperature. Most previous works use MOFs to absorb the polysulfide to solve the shuttle effect [31,53] or use MOFs as a modified layer [47]. This work uses ZIF-67 with dodecahedron structure as a filler to improve the stability, not only can improve the stability of the lithium anode but also improve the ionic conductivity and Li+ transference number. The prepared solid electrolyte evidenced a higher Li+ transference number, wider electrochemical window, and better cycling performance. In the future, the interface issues including interface contact and interface stability in ASSBs deserve more attention.
